DOC.brief_summary: The purpose of this study is to apply Anodyne therapy to active duty soldiers, who have shin splints, to evaluate healing time and effectiveness.
DOC.brief_title: Light Therapy in the Treatment of Leg Pain
DOC.detailed_description: Tibial stress reactions and fractures are often difficult to treat, and therefore, many soldiers proceed to a medical disability/discharge. It is felt that with the use of the MIRE technology, active duty soldiers with tibial stress reactions and fractures will heal more quickly and completely. All soldiers will have a documented bone scintigraph as evidence for tibial stress reaction or fracture prior to enrollment. In addition, pain-pressure goniometric measures and time to complete the Balke protocol will also be used to assess healing with the MIRE technology. Comparison: Soldiers with Active MIRE technology, compared to soldiers with Placebo MIRE technology.
DOC.criteria: Active duty soldier Exertional leg pain of greater than 3 months duration Documented bone scintigraphic evidence for tibial stress reaction or fracture Known leg Pathology other than stress reaction or fracture Service members known to be leaving area within next 6 months Pregnant females High risk cardiopulmonary patients Patients with assisted walking devices Patients with two or more cardiac risk factors
